para.paratext: Computer printouts are admissible as business records under the business records exception to the hearsay rule[1] when the business records foundation is established by an employee who is familiar with how the computer at issue is used at the particular business.[2] Finally, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-96 directs that copies of computer records “shall be received in any court of this state as primary evidence of the recitals contained therein,” meaning that a party offering a computer printout into evidence is not required to offer the original document.

See Dixon v. State, 227 Ga. App. 533, 536, 489 S.E.2d 532 (1997), which involved blood test results that were admitted after a nurse identified the computer printout showing the blood test results and testified such results were regularly entered into the hospital's computer and retrieved in the normal course of the hospital's business.

See also WGNX, Inc. v. Gorham, 185 Ga. App. 489, 490, 364 S.E.2d 621 (1988), in which a computer printout showing the amount owed by the defendant for various advertising jobs was held admissible when the print out was identified by a plaintiff's employee who explained the records were kept on the computer by the company in the regular course of the plaintiff's business.
